Kinnaur

Kinnaur is Himachal’s border district with Tibet. The landscape shifts fast: green orchards, rocky slopes, then a cold desert zone. Kinner Kailash is a constant presence over Kalpa and Peo. Villages blend Hindu devta worship and Buddhist traditions. Here you see rare chilgoza pine forests, grape vineyards, and temples carved in local wood styles.

Our Hidden Favourites

  • Roghi (near Kalpa) - Quiet village with narrow stair-lanes, old wood doors, views of the Sutlej valley. Go early in morning when mist is low.
  • Kamru Fort (Sangla side) - A wooden tower-temple complex above Sangla. Climb the steep way in. The fort's walls are wooden and stone, offering views of Baspa Valley.
  • Rakcham meadows - Flat riverbank stretches between Sangla and Chitkul, full of wildflowers in summer and bird calls.
  • Khab Confluence - Where the Spiti River meets Sutlej. The meeting of waters, the walls dropping steep, it's a visual marker of upper Kinnaur.
  • Chilgoza woods (Nichar belt) - The pine forests here produce rare pine nuts. If season is right, a local might allow a look at nut collection (always with permission).
  • Yula Kanda trek / lake (near Sangla) - A local pilgrimage trail above Sangla, leading to a high-altitude lake with a small Krishna temple.

Towns & Villages

  • Sutlej Belt:
    • Reckong Peo (2,290 m) - District headquarters, main offices, and transport hub. Brelengi Gompa nearby has a large Buddha statue from the 1992 Kalachakra.
    • Kalpa (2,960 m) - Famous for sunrise views of Kinner Kailash and terraced apple slopes. Nearby Kothi village has the Chandika Devi Temple.
    • Ribba - Known for vineyards and Angoori, a strong local grape liquor.
    • Nichar - Lower-altitude belt with warmer climate. Entry to the chilgoza pine forest region.
  • Baspa Valley:
    • Sangla (2,600 m) - Lush valley off NH-5. Features orchards, riverside stays, and the Bering Nag temple. A good base for short village walks.
    • Rakcham - Meadows along the Baspa, known for being less crowded than Sangla or Chitkul.
    • Chitkul (3,450 m) - The last inhabited village before the border. Potato and barley fields surround the Mathi Devi Temple.
  • Hangrang & Upper Side:
    • Pooh (2,750 m) - Dry, higher settlement known for apricots and an old trade-route history.
    • Nako (3,600 m) - High village with a lake, an 11th-century monastery built under Rinchen Zangpo, and a sacred rock linked to Padmasambhava.
    • Kanam / Moorang / Chango - Villages with old monasteries and forts. Chango produces good apples; Moorang has a hill fort.

Culture & Festivals

  • Phulaich / Ukhyang (Aug-Sep) - Villagers gather alpine flowers, offer them to ancestors and deities, followed by music and dance.
  • Losar (Feb) - Tibetan New Year with lamps, smoke offerings, and prayer flags in Buddhist villages.
  • Birshu (Spring) - Local new-year fair with *Deo Khel* (trance dance) and *Natti* (folk dance).
  • Sazo (Jan) - In lower Kinnaur, people bathe in springs, cook feasts, and worship village deities.
  • Suskar / Phagul (Feb-Mar) - Celebrates local peak goddesses, especially Kali Mata.
  • Dress & Ornaments - The green Kinnauri cap, woollen dohru shawl, and silver brooches are common at festivals. Everyday dress is simple woollens.

Education & Youth

  • Higher Education Anchor: The T.S. Negi Govt. College (Reckong Peo) anchors higher studies in the district, providing the main academic hub.
  • Migration for Degrees: Since schools are spread out across the mountainous terrain, many students head to Shimla, Chandigarh, or plains universities for degrees and specialized coaching.
  • Weekend Activities: Weekends are actively spent helping with **orchard work**, participating in **local festivals**, joining **trekking clubs**, and engaging in **village sports** and competitions.
  • Community Service: Youth groups actively run **clean-up drives** on the Sangla road and around Nako, especially during the tourist season, highlighting environmental responsibility.

Our Stories

Exploring the majestic peaks of the Himalayas, capturing breathtaking moments.

Immersing ourselves in the rich culture and vibrant traditions of Himachal Pradesh.

Food & Markets

  • Cuisine & Staples: The local diet focuses on hearty dishes like Siddu (steamed bread with walnut or poppy seed filling), chilra (buckwheat crêpes), and rajma-chawal. Tibetan influence brings momos and thukpa. Winter dishes include dried turnip and meat stews.
  • High Altitude Produce: Key produce includes high-quality Apples (Kalpa, Sangla), apricots (Pooh), and the rare, costly Chilgoza (pine nut from Nichar–Sangla belt).
  • Local Drinks: Local country liquor varieties include Chulli (apricot) and Angoori (grape), especially around Ribba. In upper areas, the mild barley brew Chaang is traditional.
  • Trade Hubs: The largest market for supplies is Reckong Peo Market. Eateries range from simple family-run dhabas in Kalpa to seasonal cafés in Chitkul, often featuring Tibetan cuisine in Sangla bazaar.

Travel & Geography

  • Main Route: Access is primarily via **NH-5 from Shimla** (through Rampur). Expect difficult sections like Taranda Cliff, especially during the monsoon or after fresh snow.
  • Transport: Daily **HRTC buses** run to Reckong Peo, with local buses connecting to Sangla, Chitkul, and Nako. Taxis are mainly found at Peo and Kalpa.
  • Seasons Overview:
    • April–June: Blossom and early summer. Most major roads are open.
    • July–August: Monsoon season. Landslide risk is high in lower Kinnaur, but upper Kinnaur is generally drier.
    • September–October: Best time for travel, featuring clear views and the apple harvest (Phulaich festivals).
    • November–March: Cold season. High villages receive snow, leading to partial shutdowns of routes.
  • Altitude & Health: High villages like **Chitkul (3,450 m)** and **Nako (3,600 m)** require visitors to break the journey (e.g., spending a night at Kalpa or Sangla) to prevent altitude sickness.
  • Permits:
    • Indians: No permit is needed for regular routes.
    • Foreigners: A **Protected Area Permit (PAP)** is required for travel beyond Pooh or Nako side. This must be obtained in Shimla or Reckong Peo.
  • Connectivity: Mobile service is patchy. **BSNL works best in upper Kinnaur**, while other services (Airtel, Jio) are better in the lower belts. ATMs are mainly available at Peo and Sangla.

Respect & Etiquette

  • Sacred Spaces: Remove shoes and caps before entering temples and monasteries. Keep voices low and ask before taking photos inside. Do not touch sacred objects.
  • Processions: Follow local guidance and do not stand directly in front of palanquins during *devta* processions.
  • Village Customs: Dress modestly at shrines. In some villages, follow local norms regarding women's entry into specific sanctums during menstruation (ask locally).
  • Environmental Conduct: Practice clean travel. Do not litter; carry back all plastic, diapers, and food waste.
  • Sensitive Areas: Do not take photos of army posts or check-posts. Follow all road instructions carefully, especially in landslide zones.
